Definition: In this task, you will receive a public commentary from online platforms. You are expected to divide the commentary into two classes: obscene and non-obscene. Obscenity refers to material and acts of pornography that violate the public's sense of decency.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Cataluna's a butt kicker, but she kicks the wrong butts.
Positive Examples.explanation: This is obscenity because it hints on sexual content that is offensive to the public sense of decency.

Comment: The big problem that many have pointed out is that corporations that hire undocumented labor use that illegal status to force low wages and poor working conditions on their laborers. If we had a central clearing-house of green-carded labor or some other classified labor that was constantly audited for bribery and so forth, and required all immigrant farm labor to be cleared through that system, and also if we actually cracked down on those still hiring the undocumented, then we could get good labor that still would be cheap for us but good pay for the laborer. That isn't exploitative. Of course, if you can find citizen labor sufficient to the needs of agriculture, willing and able to work for some reasonable wage, that would be great. At this point I don't believe anyone knows that such a resource exists. We may soon have to find out, though.

Comment: Wow. Almost everyone misses the real implication of this statistic. It's not a good argument for lowering tax rates on high income. An exaggerated example will illustrate.
Imagine a micronation of 100 people. The nation spends about $15,000/yr to function. Now, let's posit that 99 of the citizens earn $1/yr and 1 citizen earns $1,000,000/yr. The 99 pay taxes on wage income at 5%, each paying $0.05 (a nickel)/yr. The 1 pays taxes on capital gains and other "wealthy" forms of income at 1%, paying $10,000/yr. The nation runs at a deficit, like ours.
The "top 20%" (1 person) pays over 99% of the taxes.
As you see, that isn't a good case for lowering the top person's tax RATE.
Instead, it begs the question "how can the top be paying so much of overall taxes while paying a lower RATE than workers?
It illustrates the enormity of today's income gap. It is the OPPOSITE of an argument for reducing RATES at the top.

Comment: Seven year old Mohamed arrived at his classroom on the first day of school.
“What’s your name?”, asked the teacher.
“Mohammad,” he replied.
“You’re in Ireland now,” replied the teacher, “So from now on you will be known as Mike.”
Mohammad returned home after school.
“How was your day, Mohammad?”, his mother asked.
“My name is not Mohammad. I’m in Ireland and now my name is Mike.
“Are you ashamed of your name? Are you trying to dishonor your parents, your heritage, your religion? Shame on you!”
And his mother beat the shit out of him. Then she called his father, who beat the shit out of him again.
The next day Mohammad returned to school. The teacher saw all of his fresh bruises.
“What happened to you, Mike?”, she asked.
“Well, shortly after becoming an Irishman, I was attacked by two fucking Muslims.”

Comment: "...because I believe that racism only truly exists in the mind of recists" (sic)...",

Shortly after reporting to my Camp Pendleton duty station, I found an unsigned note in my clinic mailbox: "The Ku Klux Klan has just paid you a friendly visit--next time it'll be a REAL visit."  The note wasn't imaginary.

Nor was it a fantasy when my eight year-old daughter's white homeroom teacher reviled her in front of her entire class, because the teacher was incensed she'd successfully qualified for the school's "gifted" program, becoming the first student 'of color' therein--previously that school had never notified the parents of its majority black student body that there WAS a "gifted" program.

Nor did I imagine my son being dragged from his best friend's Corvette and beaten by Oakland cops, until they learned his best friend was Darrell Russell of the Oakland Raiders, whereupon he was released without charges.

I agree "racism" exists in YOUR mind.  As well as in objective reality.

Comment: A significant problem with the postsecondary education system is that it has become too easy for students to borrow money to pursue degrees that do not yield incomes great enough to pay back the loans. Many professors are chasing these dollars from students that really cannot afford the costs.  The competition for the easy money desired by professors is driving up the costs of education on the backs of many students that are being enslaved by the government's easy money programs.  Add in more government subsidies and the problem get worse.

Comment: I think it's rather simplistic to argue in favour of maintaining low interest rates solely to continue a useless fight that's lasted almost 10 years to boost inflation to some arbitrary number.  What's so bad about 1% or even 0% inflation that we need to target 2%?  What time and attention has the bank given to those people being hurt by this policy?  What about savers who can no longer retire on minimal returns?  What about people who would like to purchase a home but cannot due to the hugely inflated prices?

If the BoC cannot solve their problem after almost 10 years of trying then perhaps they need to re-think their strategy.  Where is the current neutral interest rate?  Does the bank really believe any interest rate rise (that keeps us below the neutral rate) will squash any hope of 2% inflation?

Comment: Oh, I'm still laughing at this column. Keillor manages to write a great humor piece while cribbing from and distorting bits from Willy S. to Jimmy Joyce. Really delightful...and here's "Introduction to Poetry" by Billy Collins, to keep the thread going.

Introduction to Poetry
I ask them to take a poem
and hold it up to the light
like a color slide
                  
or press an ear against its hive.
                
I say drop a mouse into a poem
and watch him probe his way out,
or walk inside the poem's room
and feel the walls for a light switch.
                  
I want them to waterski
across the surface of a poem
waving at the author's name on the shore.
                 
But all they want to do
is tie the poem to a chair with rope
and torture a confession out of it.
                 
They begin beating it with a hose
to find out what it really means.
—Billy Collins

Comment: I have read a fair number of articles in the MSM over the last couple of years that each make claims/references to storms, flooding and wildfires getting continually worse and causing more property damage, due to climate change.

What usually appears in these types of articles is a few people giving statements (some of them very subjective) and a few references to some municipal/regional storm damage. Very rarely have these articles shown any hard statistical data to support the claims of national long-term worsening weather/damage trends. To be clear, citing singular events in single communities/regions does not make a national trend. Also when some damage costs are stated, they are rarely compared to previous years in fixed dollar terms.

If the MSM is going to continue publishing these types of articles, can they please include long-term statistics and graphs clearly showing this trend of worsening weather and resulting increase in damage on a national scale.

Comment: Not exactly, but somewhat true.  The placebo effect is real and can be amazing, but first off it doesn't "quite often work", but it sometimes works.  Also, when it works it often isn't long lasting.  The placebo effect can have a real change in peoples'mental well being (hence feeling better) but there is little to no real evidence that there is any reversal in disease progression.  It can be noted though that a better mental state typically means less stress, and less stress can help bodies fight infections and slow the progression of some diseases.

If Hickel had made some of the settlement deals that Knowles/Bothello made, he'd have been hung from the ADN's masthead.

The State simply cannot recruit and retain the talent necessary to audit the profits of a vertically integrated multi-national company.   We gave blood in the Murkowski Administration to get Revenue's "Forensic Auditors" in the Exempt Service so they could ostensibly attract the talent for auditing both the PMV scheme and oil company taxes.   Typical State government, Revenue just used the exempt designation to hire cronies and pay them what they wanted; hence no audits for years.

Comment: Hamish,
About 30 years ago I was going on a trip and I asked all of my kids what they wanted me to bring back for them. One of my teenage foster daughters asked for a tarantula. This young lady had gone through very traumatic events in her life. She dressed in leather with spikes and had one half of her head shaved and the other half dyed purple. If she "looked" tough people would leave her alone. 
I managed to catch a tarantula while in N.M. and bought a little cage to carry it in. I covered the cage with a cloth. On the first two legs of my return trip, I had no problem. I told security (before TSA) what it was and then showed them. 
But, in LA, I was "carried" out of the security area by two huge security guards. The airline told me NO FLIGHT with the spider. I got my dander up and ended being kicked off the flight. I finally found a sympathetic airline who suggested I put it in my backpack and let a different security crew know ahead of time. Made it home a day later with it 🕷.

Comment: The U.S. tax code, and particularly the corporate income tax code, need a VAST overhaul.

The U.S. has the highest corporate tax rate in the developed world, yet manages to bring in far less revenue then many other countries.  Canada's Federal government brings in about 2.0% of GDP in corporate taxes with a Federal tax rate of 15% while the U.S. brings in only about 1.6% of GDP with a Federal tax rate of 35%.  Why?  Because their tax code is chalk full of special deductions, credits, exemptions, grants, etc. etc.

If the U.S. actually does eliminate 90%+ of their deductions, credits and the like they could easily bring in more revenue with a 15% tax rate than they do with their current 35% tax rate.  At the same time they would reduce compliance costs for companies and administrative costs for the government.

However they would lose the opportunity for politicians to pretend they are "doing something about the economy".

If you have heavy equipment you can cut big blocks of ice to build an ice wall, the pump it full of water to freeze solid.  Cover it with sawdust so the ice doesn't melt.  When the river goes out in the spring, it will change the course of the river away from the bank.  If you can get some state help, get some nitrogen rods and put them down through the ice into the bottom of the river to keep the water frozen until the river changes course.

WASHINGTON — A new batch of State Department emails released Tuesday showed the close and sometimes overlapping interests between the Clinton Foundation and the State Department when Hillary Clinton served as secretary of state.

The documents raised new questions about whether the charitable foundation worked to reward its donors with access and influence at the State Department, a charge that Mrs. Clinton has faced in the past and has always denied.

 In one email exchange, for instance, an executive at the Clinton Foundation in 2009 sought to put a billionaire donor in touch with the United States ambassador to Lebanon because of the donor’s interests there.

In another email, the foundation appeared to push aides to Mrs. Clinton to help find a job for a foundation associate. Her aides indicated that the department was working on the request.

Comment: Dennis: More thoughts on repressed memory. Last night as I was preparing to take my nightly bath, I picked up a book from the shelf of my bookcase. The books title was " A Gospel of Shame". It was co authored by Frank Bruni and Elinor Burkett. This was obviously a book I had read several years ago as the pages were starting to yellow .I read the prologue and as I started reading the first chapter, I was struck by the story of a survivor whose story was very similar to my own. Actually it was my story.  The mans' name was Frank Fitzpatrick, who was a police detective in Rhode Island. In 1989, Frank was suffering from mood swings, a lingering sense of sadness and a constant urge to cry. Frank was married,had two kids and a good job. He could not get to the root of his sadness. He tried valium and also therapy. He could not find the answers." Then , suddenly, they erupted in a jarring series of images and sensations from a past he had long blocked out."

Comment: This is a serious admonition from the Chief Justice as she steps away from the bench. Clearly McLachlin sees something she finds worrying - the threat which social media lynch mobs pose to the underpinnings of Canada's justice system, and especially to the sacrosanct presumption of innocence.  

Although directed to sexual assault, her remarks have implication across a much wider spectrum not only of our legal system but our social and cultural foundations. She does not use the words 'political correctness' but clearly that is the burgeoning, unchecked phenomena which threatens to hijack social media and drown out the rational, civil discourse that until now has molded public policy in this country. 

Social media is a tremendous innovation. But unchecked, it offers a worm hole by which specious claims and special, narrow interests can easily bypass and defeat the checks and balances so carefully built into our institutional structures over the past 150 years.

Comment: Tax avoidance and tax evasion are both highly sensitive to tax rates.  For more insight, readers might google Laffer Curve.
The exact threshold of tax rates at which tax revenues decline is a complex formula based in part on the degree of belief of the citizenry that they are receiving value for the tax that they pay.  Typically, tax rates over 50% are in the red zone, but it is important to note the additive impact of  income, consumption and asset taxes, as well as the odd head tax.  
It is pretty clear from this government's attitude on enforcement that it knows it is well  into the red zone, and each spending splurge and disbursement scandal just adds fuel to the fire that pushes taxpayers past the Laffer Curve peak.

Comment: Leave it to Catherine to present a negative case for single-payer based on flawed assumptions as to its nature.  Successful single-payer for all, will have to take on the compensation structure within the medical industry.  When in control of all medical payments, single-payer would need to regulate costs for service, not by restricting service but by limiting charges allowed for service.  Moreover, a good single-payer program would include control of medical education programs, to expand them and make programs tuition free in return for X years of service at comfortable but not extravagant pay rates.  A successful single payer program should also include the elimination of patents on drugs or perhaps a modification to allow generics with a fixed royalty paid to the developer.  No, continuation of the current system with just a nominal change in who writes the checks will not work.  The entire system needs rework.  Medical service cannot remain a gold mine for the few allowed entry.

Comment: Mental disability is not treated any differently they only classify the animal differently.  It is called emotional support animal or ESA.  And even international airlines recognize and follow the federal rules regarding these animals for American travelers.  As long as you're flying
From America to your destination and back to America.  

The fact that our local airlines dropped the damn ball is absurd.  As long as you have a letter from a doctor (doesn't matter If your disability is mental or physical) then you have a legal right to your service or ESA animal.  This not only includes flying, transport but living arrangements as well.  Places that don't accept pets must accept a service animal because it is legally not considered a pet.  Don't like the laws? Lobby against them.  But the law is the law.

Comment: "I am human, and I think that nothing human is foreign to me." Shakespeare is relevant, if approached with respect but not reverence (that might come later, might not). Romeo and Juliet is a great hook, but in upper grades, in a multicultural context, Othello is a stimulating choice. As a teen deals with a faltering grandparent, wouldn't Lear have deep resonance for the student? Part of the great joy of literature and drama is that shock of recognition over generations, that technology changes but we humans go through the same problems century in and century out. It's not just a diversion - it enriches us and can give us the tools to address our lives' pitfalls.

Of course, the teachers are crucial. If they approach Shakespeare as something to be endured rather enjoyed (like poetry, and grammar), it's no fun for anyone. Engaged by turns with gusto and sensitivity, Shakespeare speaks across time and cultures.

Comment: Whether one agrees or not that these minimum sentences are too harsh, I think the courts have been looking through the wrong end of the telescope, have misunderstood Parliament and have seriously overstepped their boundaries.

Consider this: it isn't that Parliament inadvertently caught up a so-called less serious offence in the minimum that was actually intended for more serious offences.  What Parliament in fact said is that the least serious of these offences deserves the prescribed minimum sentence.

Parliament decides these matters and enacts the laws.  Courts apply the laws as enacted.  Just because a prescribed penalty is harsh does not make it unlawful.  In the present instance Parliament intended harsh.

Comment: I recall George Brown repeatedly asking the city manager to give the Council a list of possible Opportunity Village sites a few years ago, and the manager not providing it. He has removed benches from downtown without any explicit directive from the Council. The mayor said that police took it upon themselves to remove tables and chairs from Keysey Square. The police chief is controlled by the city manager. Ruiz also closed Whoville without providing any alternative shelter, which the Council had directed him to do before shutting it down.

Eugene's council-manager system of government just doesn't work. City councilors have too little power over what the city manager does, which in some cases allows them to duck responsibility. Portland has a different system where the councilors are responsible for running city departments, and the buck stops there. It may not be as "professional", but it's more accountable. We should consider changing our system.

Comment: "if we didn't have canine teeth and were able to get our necessary vitamin B12 from plants, his avowal for nothing but plant food would be more plausible."

B12 comes from bacteria, not animals. And about your canine teeth - nearly all mammals have canine teeth. That doesn't make them meat eaters.  Saber-toothed deer, gelada baboons, white-lipped peccaries, gorillas and hippopotamuses all have fearsome canines, and the largest in the world actually belong to hippos. Their canine teeth have been known to grow up to 18 inches, but play no role in how hippos gather food.  Camels - which are herbivores - have sharp little canine teeth. By contrast humans do not. It's a stretch to even call them canines. 

There are a whole bunch of reasons why humans are biologically more fit for a vegan diet than a meat-based diet.

Comment: I recall seeing a news item on "diversity" where a black fellow who was a systems analyst was able to 'solve the problem'. Hooray and all that. 

The only problem was that as I listened to 'the problem', it was the sort of thing any competent systems analyst (regardless of colour, ethnic background, gender, sexual orientation, etc.) would have been able to solve. 

See, there are some IT problems that simply involve understanding what the problem is (often it is something like, "We need to track the number of service calls our service reps make each week."), knowing where the data is and then coming up with a way to get the data to where you want it to be. 

Sure, go ahead and advocate for 'diversity' (and certainly hire based on a person's ability). But recognize that 'reserving X number of seats for THIS group' because of 'unconscious bias' may mean you aren't hiring the best qualified people.  

btw, I wonder if the author runs an 'Equity Consulting' business?

Globalization is foremost an economic/ capitalist driven force. The rising inequality that he mentions has less to do with technology than trade, not more. The "older industries" are alive and well and flourishing in third world counties where labour is cheap.  He is referencing China as communist. "The communists are keeping the globalization faith." China hasn't been communist since Mao Zedong. The world knows it as state sponsored capitalism. The author's view is that of a rancher preparing to thin his herd. He means well, but it is not the same as being part of the herd.

Comment: Toast  back in the mid 90s when I left my full service broker I was paying $125 and at the same time a "discounted" fee of $80 via my employer's savings plan.  Rolling those fees forward 20 years the $500 while admittedly sounds high isn't that far fetched.  

That aside whether the amount is $500 or $250 doesn't change the point.

A similar issue prompted my to leave my full service broker.  The brokerage firm was bought out and I and others that I know were gradually treated to phone calls urging us to sell what would normally be considered buy and hold dividend stocks.  Clearly the new management was in favour of "active rebalancing" regardless of the client's long held objectives.

As a client of course when you aren't used to getting these types of calls and suddenly get one you are more inclined to be concerned that something is going on.  Unfortunately in those days interest information was still fairly primitive.

The positive of course is that I finally had incentive to go DIY

Comment: And like all simple solutions to complex problems, the devil's in the details.
1)  "Replacing the filter elements of the Reverse Osmosis Water Purification Unit (ROWPU) is extremely expensive..." (globalsecurity.org)
2)  Sea water won't jump into the RO tanks, it would have to be pumped from an ocean  intake pipe, with its own obvious logistical problems and costs, especially here.
3)  The potable water at sea level would then have to be chlorinated and pumped to it's users.
4)  This scenario is starting to look like a desalination plant, typically requiring 25 acres at the shoreline, high energy costs, and negative environmental impact where the salt is discharged. http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0011916402010573?via%3Dihub
5)  Re. Slingshot, drinking distilled water with zero minerals causes long-term health problems, and the Stirling motor is suspect.
6)  https://www.quora.com/Is-Dean-Kamens-SlingShot-water-purifier-viable

Comment: Whether the teachers are legislated back to work will not resolve either their personal and professional frustrations, nor will it begin to address the underlying issues in schools and classrooms. But, neither would an agreed upon new contract achieve these same ends.

Like many workers, and particularly public sector workers, teachers want the salaries and benefits they think they are entitled to, despite the declining ability in Nova Scotia of the government to fund all of the public services people here have become used to. Like other professionals, teachers want to be able to create good outcomes for all students, and are finding this much more difficult given the increasing and more diverse expectations placed on them by, not government, but by we the public and we the parents.

We need radically new alternatives. These are not going to come either from a negotiated contract, nor from a legislated return to work. So we wait again for effective leadership on all sides.

Your logic is flawed, Rik.  Why would an insurance company lobby for fluoridation?  .  .  What does an insurance company do?

So, if Mrs. Firman is paid to lobby for Delta (and who knows if that's true) then it must be because Delta has decided that water fluoridation is good for the oral health of the community . . because then they'll have to pay out Less in claims.  Get it?

"In the case of the NFL, those kneeling should be allowed to explain their symbolic action. You say they're not showing disrespect to the flag or the anthem, but that's false. Suppose instead of kneeling at the consecration, I stood as a protest against racism. cont

Comment: During a recent BOG testimony it was revealed that moose will not eat willows high or higher in tannin. That is why you will see moose eat some willows and avoid seemingly the same willow plant elsewhere. Not all willow is considered edible by moose and they know which ones they are. Interesting. However the statement "Both plants contain bacteria-killing tannins that disrupt fermentation without interfering with a cow's digestion." is flat wrong. The way a ruminants digestion system works is by fermentation and disrupting it or killing the bacteria is disrupting the process. Bacteria do the work and in turn the ruminants digest the bacteria particularly for protein. Dead bacteria do not reproduce and fewer bacteria to digest means less protein and that means less meat per feed input. Simple as that.

Comment: And as a counterpoint to all those guns, the Swiss are also very trusting and community-minded, even if generally very reserved.

Once after a long journey and running low on cash, on a late-night train from Geneva to a town in Switzerland as a teen, a Swiss middle-aged person asked me how I was going to get home since all the local trains had stopped running.    I wasn't sure, said I thought I'd walk, and when they asked how long the walk was and I said six hours, they gave me CHF 50 (about C$75 in today's money) and told me to get a licensed taxi at the station.    The person also gave me a card with their address and said I could send them the money if I wanted to.

The next day I mailed them the funds in the morning with a note thanking them.  I'm sure they received it the same day in the afternoon -- that's how reliable the mail service was.

Trust in society is a big part of what makes people contented and as close to anxiety-free as can be.

Comment: Not quite. I understand that the Eucharist was initially celebrated within the context of a full meal, presumably with the blessing of the bread at the beginning and the blessing of the cup at the end, exactly as research suggests occurred at the last supper. Paul appears to provide the earliest evidence for the pulling together of the blessing of bread and wine into one ritual within the context of the meal. It is the service of readings, a direct imitation of the synagogue service, that was initially separate from, but eventually combined with the Eucharist; and it is the meal that was initially combined with, but eventually separated from the Eucharist, and then called called the agape.

The best book ever written, IMHO, on the HISTORY of the liturgy is Gregory Dix (Anglican), Shape of the Liturgy. His presentation is completely multi-ritual, with equal weight to all eastern varieties as well as western. A fundamental rule is liturgical innovation was always from East to West.

Comment: A deduction that EVERYONE gets is not a subsidy (like a personal exemption for yourself).  But a deduction that's selective (i.e. some get it and some don't) is a form of backhanded subsidy.

That's because in order to raise the same amount of total revenue, the base rates have to increase as more and more selective deductions are subtracted out of the total.  For you to pay $1000/yr less in taxes because of that mortgage interest deduction, others have to pay $1000 more to make up the difference (via higher rates).

That means the ones paying more because they don't get that mortgage interest deduction are effectively subsidizing the ones that do get it.  Without that deduction, it evens the taxation out to where no one is getting (or paying for) that subsidy.  Making it more fair and equitable taxation.

And that's true for most deductions. Like state/local taxes. Federal taxpayers in low tax states subsidize those in high tax states now via that deduction.

Comment: Surely you are kidding in your (I'm assuming jestful) curiosity in regards to the witnesses who were or weren't called? You do understand, in America, that the prosecution has an obligation to try a case that 'must stand on its own merits.' The admission of alleged, yet uncharted, acts that have no material relevancy to the case at bar (404(b) evidence) is inadmissible, save for some very specific exceptions. Comment: The PERS payments have to be made by law. Measure 97 makes sure that the other kinds of bills can be paid, too. Our tax structure is a wreck, and Measure 97 fixes it. In other cases, they will absorb costs or make other changes. Measure 97 is a thoughtful and effective way for Oregon to address its needs. It will help to stabilize our tax structure as we head into a demanding future. Without it, we are going to have to start destroying things. We've done that in the past, and it sets us behind for years and years.

Comment: Spruce Aphid are preferential to Norway, Sitka, and Blue spruce.  Most insects are very particular about their target species.  I don't think the leaf miners have much to worry about when it comes to wasp predation, since they are encased within the leaf itself.  they might be attacked by parasitoid wasps (the life cycle of Sigourney Weaver's Alien is based off of those guys), but as far as I am aware, the primary biological control for leaf miners are soil nematodes and fungi.  The leaf miners overwinter in the duff layer, and are vulnerable to attack until they emerge as adults.  

As far as the general system goes, Beetles and Fire are the natural cleansing agents of the forest.  think of the forest as a herd, and those two agents as wolves, picking off the weak and sick trees.  The system functions in that manner rather well under normal conditions, but when the climate began a major regime shift here in the 80's, it triggered the largest bark beetle outbreak ever recorded (cont'd)

Comment: I'm familiar with VREAA - didn't recall that s/he had data going back that far. What's striking to me is inflation-adjusted prices (red line).
https://vreaa.files.wordpress.com/2013/01/van_house_price_1960_2012.png

In inflation-adjusted dollars, the 1980s peak comes up to maybe half of the adjust price in 2011. And that's before prices effectively doubled again to the present. Vancouver has never had affordability so divorced from incomes.

It's common to reference interest rates vs. prices. I'd trade the present for lower prices and higher rates in a heartbeat. Why? Because each year you delayed buying, you amassed a bigger % of down payment by saving. Today, the reverse is true: each year delay, you fall further behind. That dynamic did not exist for extended periods in this region until the most recent decade - and that marks a HUGE difference. It can take 2-4 times longer to amass the same % down payment now as compared to the past - and that assumes prices don't keep rising.

Comment: The Swedes have a name for this: döstädning. It means "death cleaning." The idea is to declutter your home before you die so your crap isn't a burden on your heirs who have to deal with it all.
Having spent 20 yrs in the military, moving about every two years or so, I learned the importance of not keeping stuff you don't really need or want. We tend to fill the available space in our living quarters.
Look around you. Think about the last time you used that old exercise equipment or that third TV. And never mind all the rubbish in your junk drawer. Why keep it all?

Comment: Fact Check:  Unfortunately, *Snopes* is not a valid source for objective truth.  Please utilize an objective, non-partisan source.

Fact Check:  The Chaplain of the United States House of Representatives is one of the officers of the U.S. Congress, cited in the first half of Article 1, Section 2, Clause 5 of the United States Constitution as giving it the authority to elect a Chaplain, "The House of Representatives shall choose their speaker and other Officers."  In addition to opening proceedings with prayer, the Chaplain provides pastoral counseling, and coordinating scheduling of guest chaplains.  While Chapalins don't have to be, they have all of them been Christian since inception.

*https://archive.org/details/congressionalrec110bunit*

*Guest Chaplains*, recommended by congressional members to deliver the session's opening prayer in place of the House Chaplain, have represented many different religious groups, including Judaism and Islam.

Comment: Yes, of course basic research is vital.  From basic research has come most of our profound breakthroughs in understanding.  It is not necessary to argue that gravity waves might be useful in themselves as it is incredibly unlikely that they will given the energy scale at which they exist.  It is the knowledge and, as pointed out, the ability to detect them that has value.  Comparison to the transistor is not valid in terms of application.

By the way, the construction of two detectors was not just to validate detection as in duplicate.  Gravity waves travel at the speed of light which is fast but not instantaneous.  The signals observed at the two detectors are thus delayed copies of each other.  The time delay signifies traveling gravity waves and even helps determine the direction from which they came.

Comment: Personally I think Trump is the most appalling president the USA has chosen in a long time. However on this point he is on solid ground. The accusations that the Russians influenced the US election is pure politics, played by the Obama administration.

We may take it as a given that there's cyber intrusions into the networks of political parties in every country of interest. The IT infrastructures of political parties are likely to be much easier to penetrate than government networks. But at the same time a great deal of valuable information can be obtained. In all likelihood those intrusions come from both foreign and domestic sources.

Now to the point: the public report issued by the FBI and Homeland security identified two breaches of the Democrats IT network. The report does not say what, if anything, was obtained in those breaches. The FBI and HS do not say that the election was influenced by that breach. That claim is made by the Obama administration, only.

Comment: Here is another view.  The older areas of Honolulu have seen drastic drops in enrollment at East Oahu Schools.  So should Kaiser, Kalani, and Kaimuki High Schools combine to field a single team along the lines of what Pac-Five has done as a conglomerated team of smaller private schools?   I can see the same at Kailua High School where enrollment is now below 800 students, which is probably close to the size of a graduating class was 30 years ago.  The point I'm making is that the Baby Boom ended 30 years ago, and these subsequent generations have deliberately smaller family sizes in Windward or East Oahu, so of course their schools are shrinking.  And all of this combined with the emerging evidence of CTE-related brain injuries are have a reductive effect on football participation in general.

Comment: Who gives a crap where the word originated. I spoke about definition, not etymology. 

It's utterly irrelevant where it originated or what it meant when it was created. What matters is what it means today, what people understand when they hear it. Not what it meant once upon a time.

The word "proves"used to mean "to test and show to be false", giving English the expression "the exception that proves the rule" - which literally meant "the exception that shows the rule isn't actually a rule and is not really true".

Over time "proves" lost the meaning of "to show the falsehood of" and only the meaning of "to show it's true" remained, and the proverb survives even though it's modern day meaning makes no sense. It's a kind of bizarre claim that the the rule is true BECAUSE there are exceptions to it.

Words change their meanings over time - and if you don't know the current meaning, you cannot communicate honestly, logically or usefully.

Comment: The comment system here is generally successful.  Personal attacks do not survive for very long, and the comments do not require constant supervision by Civil Beat employees.  There are some irritating issues, but in general, debate is not discouraged.  I use a persistent pseudonym, because most of my views are minority opinions.  It only takes one kook who is determined to "punish" the writer of an unpopular opinion, to make it not worth the effort to write anything at all, unless the writer enjoys arguing.  My full disclosure:  I am not paid by anyone.  I do not belong to any organizations except a church (of which I am very skeptical).  I do not even know anyone in a position of power.  I post most often about rail, gun control, politics, and journalism.  I hope to ride the rail system someday, I have an old and slightly-used gun, I vote, and I value journalism as a potential (but mostly ineffective) check and balance against government power.  I avoid Facebook like the plague.

Comment: Very common place. The 'list' is  a holding pattern t hat has been generated by VA not paying its bills: 
The physician places a request for services ( such as orthopedics) 
Clerks (yes  clerks approves a physician's request) maybe with some direction from the Chief of Staff
The request  just sits there because in our area most orthopedic offices are not accepting VA patients due to failure of reimbursement  under CHOICE and non-VA Care programs
The Veteran calls the physician angry at waiting for months for a referral
The physician or their nurse checks the status of the referral and determines that it was approved but time to use it has expired.
The clerk then tells you that  a new consult has to be placed  because the approved consult has expired (was never used; no appointment was given). 
Placing a new consult starts a  new  referral action and  resets time of action on the orthopedics request back to zero even though Veteran still has not seen ortho! 
VA finest cooking the books!

Comment: There maybe a little blood left in the turnip but the ride on the gravy train is over.

In the early 80's we were number two in oil production and had a significant share of the nation's oil.  At this point, we could call the shots and make aggressive demands.  

Now, Alaska is number 4 in oil production and losing ground fast...how fast?  Texas production is 7 times higher, ND 2.5 times higher.  California produces 15% more oil than Alaska.  Our production rate is comparable to Oklahoma and New Mexico. Except their trend is up.  At this rate, we will be #6 by the close of the decade.    https://www.eia.gov/dnav/pet/pet_crd_crpdn_adc_mbblpd_a.htm

In terms of NG reserves....we aren't even in the top 5 http://www.eia.gov/naturalgas/crudeoilreserves/

By no means should we sell out or be subservient to energy extractors....but if we do not recognize that Alaska needs oil producers far more than oil producers need Alaska our stuggle will get worse.

Comment: Thomas Darcy McGee: As far as I can tell, the link you cite provides no analysis of the relationship between immigration levels and differential rates of economic growth. During the pre-WWI period of mass immigration, when we experienced the highest immigration rate in our history, economic growth was apparently anemic, if one is to infer anything from the link. But in the post WWII period, aggregate economic growth was generally consistent throughout periods both of high immigration (1950s) and lower immigration (1970s). So, what conclusions can one infer? My guess is that immigration isn't particularly relevant to per capita economic gains although it may increase aggregate economic growth. Canada maintained high levels of non-European immigration during the decade between 2005 and 2015, where we experienced the worst real growth record since the 1930s, further undermining the argument that a beneficial economic impact applies.

Comment: Motley, what happened? I find myself agreeing with you!  Certainly 2020.
However, regarding the problems of the "American System" I can't say the Parliamentary system is necessarily better, though it may seem so at the moment.  It may depend on the situation, and there's always the delicate balance between stability and flexibility -- frequent governments rising and falling  isn't productive and can lead to extremism.

And then there's the question of multi-party vs. two-party.  Again, it's easy to think the votes are greener on the other side of "the Pond", with some  having multiple parties--this leads to more expression of minority positions -- good-- but sometimes chaos as well.

And what about the Electoral College vs. popular vote?  Currently popular opinion, especially  among Democrats, is strongly against the EC, but we can think of other situations where we'd prefer the Electoral College.
All three of these questions deserve serious debate though I don't see any as "The Key."

Comment: Densification of  the Lower Mainland is already well on it's way. Burnaby is allowing hi-rises in the Metrowtown, Lougheed Mall area,  and Brentwood area with many more to come. Richmond along #3 road, Coquitlam in the Ioco area and also the Coquitlam Centre area. Surrey has hi-rises being built in it's city centre as well as the Guildford area. 

Many of the suburban communities are allowing very few single family lots. The majority are townhouses as well as 5 story condos. The suburban communities are also less dense because streams and watercourses have to be protected. In Vancouver they were just filled or diverted by underground pipes. Also the suburban communities have the ALR land that is protected. These lands will never be built on so that does affect overall density.

Vancouver is more dense because people want to live there. If you suggest to anyone in Vancouver that they could buy in Surrey or Coquitlam for far less money they will thumb their nose at it.

Comment: Let me put it to you in another context, it might help:

How would Pope Francis have dealt with the clergy sex abuse crisis, if he, instead of JPII, had been Pope in 1985?

Think about it.

Do we really know if Francis would have acted any different from JPII?

I don't think there is any way to know this.   We think Francis is the more more enlightened, humane and caring Pope on sex abuse, but then again,  Francis has the benefit of living through the errors of his predecessors, the times  they lived in, etc.

The same goes for American presidents.

That is, Obama wasn't president during 911, so we really can only guess what he would have done with Iraq and Iran.

It's quite easy to say Obama would  have pursued a gentle way of talking with the Middle East, avoiding all military conflict.   

But as with the Francis example, Obama had the advantage of not being president when such decisions were made.  

So no, I don't think much about an "Obama doctrine" as something to salute.

Comment: Are you going to not wear helmets while you wait for this mythical no-risk infrastructure? Where is this nirvana that causes you to skip a helmet on occasion? Even if there were a system of bike paths with no possible car contact, there would still be accidents and head injuries due to equipment malfunction - yours or a nearby rider, errant wildlife, icy pavement, etc. I have a kid alive today because he wore a helmet on a quiet country road with no car in sight, but difficult to detect damage to pavement from tree roots in shadow that caused his bike to flip end over end downhill.

Protecting yourself with available safety equipment should be every rider's first priority in the real world. You can get pretty banged up waiting for perfection.

Comment: "it isn't the landlord's job to make housing affordable"

But housing is a social resource, so clearly the government has a role to play. You can't easily live outdoors in this country. Governments in most advanced countries either provide a large supply of subsidized units and/or institute effective rent controls to ensure that ordinary people can afford to live in large cities. At the very least, governments should ensure that those people, like seniors and the disabled, who live in large cities should be able to do so. For people like me who have impaired eyesight and can no longer drive and/or physical impairments and lack mobility, living in the middle of nowhere is not an option. With an aging population, rental stress will lead to many negative outcomes, no doubt including a higher suicide rate among seniors and the disabled. If that's what society wants for the sake of juicing profits, that's what it'll get.

Comment: Lucy Vinis appears to be a decent person; and, although I support Clark, I hope folks don't trash talk her the way that Piercy's first campaign did in their slimy attacks on Nancy Nathanson.
 
Here are some facts:

1. Vinis's experience is in fund raising. I have close friends who are "development directors" and they are exceptional at what they do. However, they're not doing the job of an "Executive Director," and their experience is of limited value for a Mayor's tasks.

Comment: Let's be honest, the pledge to lower debt-to-GDP has LONG since been tossed in the garbage, any claim otherwise is just a rouse to fool the naive.

The reality is that the world, right now, is in a period of economic strength that won't last very long.  Canada may have some local weakness due to low oil prices, but when the world economy turns bad today's "slow growth" will be seen as the good times.

When (not if) that happens our current smallish deficits will balloon.

There is little doubt in my mind that our Federal debt-to-GDP ratio will exceed 35% by the time the next election is called and many provinces will be just as bad if not worse off.

Comment: My thoughts and prayers are with the families and my brothers and sisters in blue in Dallas.   I am tremendously saddened by the loss of life and the hijacking of a peaceful protest by these murderers.  There were two officer involved shootings this week, but neither was in Dallas - neither involved this department, this city or these people (the protestors or the police).  Those shootings deserve a full and fair inquiry and those shooting victims too deserve justice.  But tonight I watched Dallas turn into a combat zone, with a military style operation targeting police officers who were there simply to protect the very people protesting them.  And when those officers began to go down - assassinated by a team of snipers; instead of running away - they helped civilians, covering them, evacuating them and doing what we expect police officers to do.  I have never been more proud of a police department since the valiant efforts of the NYPD and NYFD in the wake of 9/11.

Comment: During the Wojtyla/Ratzinger years, we witnessed a gradual, but not subtle, emergence of a new ultramontanism that is aptly called "creeping" (creepy!) infallibility. Infallibility was often invoked (not always explicitly) in a way that tends to collapse the traditional articulation of distinct levels of authority and response. For instance, Pope John Paul never explicitly invoked infallibility to shore up his teaching about the ordination of women; neither did Pope Benedict. But Cardinal Ratzinger, as prefect of the CDF, did; in doing so, Ratzinger did not in any respect add to or detract from what JP had already written. 
I bring this up to argue that this fuzzy way of thinking about church teaching, about authority, response and reception of church teaching, about conscience formation has a provenance in recent papacies. Trad and RR both evince ignorance of the Catholic tradition; but they may have heard these distortions in Catholic classrooms or pulpits in the past 25 years.

Comment: No, as I understand it a laicized priest (or deacon) should never be permitted to distribute Holy Communion, since they are forbidden to exercise their priestly ministry (except for hearing a deathbed confession).
It may seem overly technical but it isn't really:
You might think that they can be extraordinary ministers of Holy Communion, but only a layperson can be that. A laicized priest (or deacon) is NOT a layperson, they remain ordained. Therefore their act of distributing Communion would be a forbidden exercise of their priestly ministry as an Ordinary minister of Holy Communion (not extraordinary).

Comment: We have our own act to clean up.  

We need to get people to stop dumping plastic and clothing into the ocean. Microplastics and microfibers can break down to microscopic size and even become sub-cellular, penetrating inside living animal cells.  While we don't have long-term health studies for human impacts, none of the research on wild birds or mammals suggests anything other than chronic and progressive health problems as a result of ingesting these microparticles.  That's just as scary as drug residue.

There's a lot of challenges at once for ocean management, but making sure we don't dump so much trash in the ocean here is one that we can control.

Comment: The wishes of the majority of US voters was ignored. The EC system in the US literally makes those up to 49.999% of actual votes just disappear in all but 2 States.

The result was that in 3 small swing States, about 70,000 votes 'trumped' those of nearly 3 million MORE votes in the other 47 States. Actually, the 3 million more votes that were cast for Clinton than for Trump don't even take into account the other votes for candidates. If you add them in, a total of 11,119,360 MORE votes were cast for someone else than FOR him. That would be the true "wishes of the majority", - of ALL voters - but the EC system doesn't work that way.

If all States' EC voters' votes were apportioned on a percentage basis instead of 'winner take all', then the "wishes of the (actual) majority" - of the entire populace - would be ACCURATELY reflected in the outcome. Not to re-hash the results of the election, just decrying that the EC system does not reflect the actual will of the majority of US voters.

Comment: [Fairness isn't about playing "favorites."]
You honestly believe it is fair to censor speech that you feel offended or disrespected here?  Anyone can claim they are offended or disrespected so who is supposed to judge what are valid claims and not?  And how are they going to make those judgments without opening themselves to "playing favorites?"
IMO, it is wiser, when it comes to speech, to run a free hand than to deal with the ever escalating issue of what is "offensive, "hateful," etc. as there are always new situations and new circumstances that will require a new review of the rules and standards to be "fair" to those who are about to be censored.  Even the Supreme Court is reticent to determine what is and isn't "fair" when it comes to speech and approach the issue from an oblique angle of what is and is not "protected" rather than what is "fair."
This is an interesting topic for discussion and I want to continue it but I'm going to busy so it'll likely be a while before I respond

Comment: Hardly. Weather patterns vary with solar cycles. In addition to the 11 year cycle most people are familiar with, there are more extended cycles that result in "little ice ages" and major cooling and warming trends. Actual climatologists are trying to figure out what sort of cycle we are in, now. Our sun is acting very strangely - two South poles, a huge whole, a lack of sun spots, and swarms of solar storms. The fact is, they don't know if we're in a cooling or warming cycle. None of this, however, is due to human actions.

Human caused climate change is complete or mostly fiction. Climatologists, atmospheric scientists, and astronomers pretty much universally agree with that. Pollution is another story, however. Acid rain, from burning fossil fuels, desertification of landscape by removing vegetation and diverting water, etc. are quite real. You ignore those real problems, in favor of "green energy" corporate scams. Pay attention to the real problems we can do something about.

Comment: "have a high-rise survival plan ready at all times"

This is especially needed at high-rises that are located near obvious hazards like freight railways and transmission pipelines. A railway accident could require that large numbers of people be evacuated under extreme conditions: a leak of ammonia or chlorine gas, fuel tankers exploding, etc.

The situation is different with respect to pipelines. Unlike railways which are highly visible, pipelines are buried and unless someone happens to notice the marker and, more importantly, understands what it represents, they will have no clue that they are living next to something that could suddenly spray their building with flammable liquid.

I have posted information on this issue for the past three days. This follows five years of working with authorities at all three levels (federal, provincial and municipal) to address the issue of unsafe development next to pipelines. City planners continue to allow schools, seniors facilities and [TBC]

Comment: I'd like to think a single payer would work, but the U.S. government has proven it cannot run an integrated health system.  One such example is the VA.  Medicaid is consuming more of the budget quite simply because there are more people consuming healthcare.  When something is free, you use more of it - it is really that simple.  If you read some of the hospital rating reports, the idea that increasing the Medicaid eligibility has backfired as the increased volume (e.g. new patients who've never accessed the health system before) and transfer of patients to Medicaid from commercial insurance (due to the ACA regulations around minimum coverage causing small biz to drop plans) has outweighed the reductions in charity care write-offs.  

I wish it were otherwise, but Americans  want to be lazy, eat like crap, consume drugs legal or illegal, and at the same time demand their right to free healthcare.  Unlike countries were single payer works, there is no social contract to be responsible.

Comment: This is more common than you may think.  I was 1 of 4 Jewish kids in a large high school in eastern PA.  The amount of crap I took from teachers and/or administrators because I am not Christian was pretty damn frustrating.  That crap was everything from being sent to detention for not wanting to sing Christmas songs praising Jesus as a part of a required Christmas pageant, to being told pointedly that I would fail a class if I missed a day for the Jewish High Holidays.  Those holidays happen early enough in the school year that there is no way I wouldn't be able to make up the work, but since the teacher had scheduled a test for that day, with no way to make it up, I was out of luck as far as he was concerned.  Thankfully, my parents are both incredibly pushy and managed to make most of the problems go away without resorting to suing.

As for the Christmas songs, I would have been fine if they had been the secular Rudolph and Santa type songs, but not full on religious ones.

Comment: Food combining claims to make digestion easier as long as you keep starch and meat separated. Meat & veg, or starch and veg are ok, but no starch and meat together. That's it. My father rigorously "food combined" for about a decade when I was a kid, and a little less stringently so for the past 30+ years. He followed the simple premise of no starch and no meat together, along with only eating fruit until noon each day, that he lost so much weight so quickly that people asked him if he was suffering from something serious! He would respond that he was 'food combining' long before anyone else seemed to have heard of it. Never an overweight man, my dad used food combining, and simply walking to/from his office downtown everyday to keep his weight and fitness in a good way for decades. Based on my father's experience - I would say food combining not only helped with his digestion but had serious weight loss benefits. Like with any other lifestyle change - just check with your GP first.

Comment: The differences between tax dollars going to support public education, and being split off to private "choice" is quite complicated and needs to be understood. Private schools and many charter schools do NOT have the same oversite, admission policies, and requirements that public schools do. Taking money away from public schools is simply hurting all the programs that support educating every single child with a quality education. There is not enough money now for public schools, young college graduates are not coming into the profession as the demands are far too great, and the pay too low. Public tax dollars go to schools that support separation of church and state in regards to education.  They teach about the theory of evolution, and concrete scientific evidence of global warming, whereas some religious private schools do not. Unfortunately most states public education systems are chronically underfunded, they need more support, not less!

2. Something will bite Trump in the ass and result in something hurting the US on an international level, and result in fallout on the international level. Take your pick what this is? Comment: I'm not about to start making predictions five games into the season. They look good right now but they could hit a bad stretch at any time, and then we'll see what they're really made of. But watching this team so far, it seems clear what Bednar and Sakic have been trying to build: a fast skating and fast thinking team that puts pressure on the opponent and then takes advantage of their mistakes. They have yet to face a team that's playing great--the Ducks are a very good team but were missing some key guys--but even so, they're fun to watch, they seem to be having fun playing the game, and maybe most importantly, they're controlling the play more than they're reacting to it.

Supposedly there were a bunch of scouts in attendance last night. Let them watch, but I really hope Sakic isn't thinking about trading anybody right now. Let's allow this team to gel and see what they can do for the next couple months, rather than blow it up with a trade.

Comment: ½ of this year's growth has been the result of a recovery in the oil sector - what you called putting all our eggs in one basket. That is unsustainable.

YoY comps were at the most flattering in May since May 2016 was the biggest decline in oil -  0.6% of GDP at the time. That comparison drops out, in June, so the rate of growth slows even if output continues to rise - it's called the base effect. It's one of the reasons the expectation for H1 growth were so high, but the whole of 2017 was lower

Forecasts for h2 and next year are for a slowing economy - higher based effect and lower growth. Average forecasts for the whole year are 2.7%, and 2% next (so forecasts 100% support my assertion). 

So 4.6% slows to 2.7% slows to 2% - draw that on a piece of paper and it will look remarkable like the kind of peak you find in economic text books and exactly the environment Keynes said we should NOT be running deficits.

Something more than RRSPs is required to level this playing field.

Comment: Sorry Lumen, I object vehemently to the attempt to associate oppressive bureaucracy as an inherent component of socialism. That notion arises entirely from the Soviet system that centralized virtually all modes of production; and even then, fairness requires comparing that bureaucracy to the enormous corporate income tax bureaucracy in capitalism (both in government and industry) which the soviets did not have.

There are other ways to socialize production (without the stupidity of soviet centralization) that require no more bureaucracy that in capitalism--a government can be the sole shareholder in an airline or railway or steel plant, and just receive dividends, for instance. 

More importantly, the elements of social economy being considered these days are not the means of production, but rather the provision of social services.

More or less bureaucracy is, I suggest, ultimately a function of government rather than economic system. There is more than one way to skin a cat.

Comment: Gold does not "combine" with mercury.  Gold adheres to mercury.  Both remain unchanged in this process.  During the multiple American gold rushes the larger pieces of placer gold were easy to pick out of the gravel in which they were found.  The miners would use a sheet of copper, cleanse it with sulfuric acid, and coat it with mercury.  The gravel containing the finer bits of gold was then washed over the mercury coated copper plate and the gold stuck to it.  The mercury-coated gold was scraped off the plate and this was heated to vaporize the mercury.  Native gold is usually about 18-20 karat.  To purify the gold it was mixed with borax and heated to high temperature.  The gold melted, the impurities combined with the borax, everything cooled down, the slag was chipped away and Voila!  24 carat pure gold.

Comment: If this will "cost us billions", where will those billions go? Well, they'll go to jobs paying to clean up factories, manufacture cleaner energy production, etc.

We're going to have to get cleaner eventually. As the earth heats up, we'll have more health issues, food supply problems, and run our air conditioners demanding even more energy. The question is, do clean up now and get it over with, or do we pass it on to our children, where it will be much much more expensive, in terms of lives and money?

Putting our fingers in our ears shouting "la la la, climate change is not man-made, la la la" is not going to make the problem go away. We have to decide when to act. It seems to me, the sooner, the better.

Comment: The Church has it mixed up. Chastity is not defined by what one does or does not do with emotions, affections, and physical expressions. Comment: The failure of our education system is dispiriting.

Trade economics does not resemble a bank account. It is deeply unfortunate that politicians seem to be able to talk about it in this way and a large number of people appear to be buying into it wholesale.

For instance, while trade deficits exist, there is no equivalent notion of a current account 'debt'. We are not paying them interest for imports that exceed our exports. There is no certainty that we will have to 'pay it back' in any meaningful way. It's complicated. Ultimately things have to balance out, and when they don't the exchange rate shifts to compensate. The money that we use to buy Chinese imports *has to come back to Canada for something*, because there is simply no place else for Canadian dollars to go.

Comment: In the cumulative effect of the events describe in my opening post, the danger is that 

(a) Mexico elects a populist Government in the upcoming election (around June, I believe) & begins matching Trump's posturing bravado for domestic political purposes, &

(b) confusion reigns regarding NAFTA in the run-up to the US midterm elections as pro & anti-NAFTA elements in both the GOP & Democratic Parties harden their positions.

NAFTA in its current form would remain in force but politics, markets & forward planning by Governments, industries, corporations, etc. would be impeded for a protracted period.
